repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Second National Agricultural
            Extension Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was
            unsatisfactory, while sustainability is unlikely. The rating
            is consistent with the fact that, given only partial
            achievement of the immediate objectives of the project, it
            is unlikely that institutional development, as supported by
            the project, will be financially sustainable, in light of
            the existing, and future, levels of Government funding, and,
            it further spells out the absence of increased awareness,
            and adoption, of improved technologies, a key assumption
            within the project. The performance of the Bank is assessed
            as deficient, both in terms of preparation and appraisal, as
            well as supervision, due to a consistent lack of objectivity
            regarding the actual impact, and likely sustainability of
            the project. Similarly, the performance of the borrower, who
            did not comply with most of the legal covenants, is rated
            unsatisfactory. Several lessons are drawn from the project,
            namely, that to ensure cost effectiveness of extension
            operations, funding should be identified at the earliest
            stages, and, if contribution difficulties arise, operations
            should be scaled down to appropriate funding levels. In
            addition, the design process must incorporate realistic risk
            assessment of key policy, institutional, and financial
            aspects, to adequately influence project outcomes, while
            more analytical rigor should be introduced for supervision,
            and, management should account for clearly defined responsibilities.

18156363.theme: Rural services and infrastructure,Gender,Export development and competitiveness
18156363.trustfund:
TF020400-NETHERLANDS' CONSULTANTS
            TRUST FUND,TF031777-KENYA - AGRICULTURE RESEARCH

repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Second National Agricultural
            Extension Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the project is to
            increase the rate of adoption and stimulate the development
            of technical packages that will enable smallholder farmers
            to increase their productivity and incomes.  The project
            includes investments to strengthen the major components of
            an extension service.  On organization and management, funds
            will be provided for: (i) investments and operation support
            necessary to strengthen the extension service, expand it to
            six new areas, and develop two prototypes in arid and
            semi-arid areas; (ii) transportation to increase staff
            mobility and enable them to work with groups; (iii)
            divisional offices; (iv) office, field and training
            equipment; (v) a computerized monitoring system on a pilot
            basis; (vi) technical assistance in procurement, accounting
            auditing; and (vii) impact assessment, organization, and
            staff deployment studies.  On extension methodology, the
            project will fund:  (i) improved use of mass media and
            better communications; (ii) rehabilitation and furnishing of
            Farmer Training Centers; and (iii) establishment of two
            Farmer Service Centers on a pilot basis.  On training, the
            project supports: (i) a review of the curricula and
            operations of agricultural educational institutions; (ii)
            degree training; (iii) courses to retrain staff in crop and
            livestock production; (iv) regular training sessions; and
            (v) orientation courses.  On research, funds will be
            provided for transportation and equipment.
